Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First, I think I need to calculate the total resolution time for each case. That means from when the ticket is received until it's closed. I'll go through each case one by one.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 101: It's received at 8:00, then triaged at 8:10, assigned at 8:20, investigated at 9:00, resolved at 10:00, and closed at 10:15. So, the total time is from 8:00 to 10:15, which is 2 hours and 15 minutes.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 102: Received at 8:05, triaged at 8:30, assigned at 9:00, escalated at 11:30, investigated at 14:00, resolved at 9:00 next day, and closed at 9:15. So the total time from 8:05 on March 1st to 9:15 on March 2nd. That's almost 24 hours and 10 minutes.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 103: Received at 8:10, triaged at 8:15, assigned at 8:30, investigated at 8:45, resolved at 9:15, closed at 9:30. So total time is 1 hour and 20 minutes. That's pretty quick.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 104: Received at 8:20, triaged at 9:00, assigned at 9:30, investigated at 13:00, resolved at 8:00 next day, closed at 8:30 next day. So total time from 8:20 on March 1st to 8:30 on March 2nd. That's about 24 hours and 10 minutes.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 105: Received at 8:25, triaged at 8:35, assigned at 9:00, investigated at 9:10, escalated at 10:00, then investigation again at 14:00 on March 2nd, resolved at 9:00 on March 3rd, closed at 9:30. So total time is from 8:25 on March 1st to 9:30 on March 3rd. That's about 49 hours and 5 minutes. That's the longest by far.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: So, the cases with significantly longer times are 102, 104, and 105. Cases 101 and 103 are within the expected time frame.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, looking for root causes. Cases 102, 104, and 105 all had escalations. Escalation usually means the issue was more complex and needed a higher level of support, which can take longer.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Also, in Cases 102 and 104, there was a delay between the escalation and the investigation. For example, in 102, it was escalated at 11:30 but the investigation started the next day at 14:00. Similarly, in 104, it was escalated but the investigation was on March 2nd at 14:00, which is a day later.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Another factor is the time between activities. In 105, the investigation after escalation on March 2nd was at 14:00, and resolution was on March 3rd at 9:00. Thatâ€™s another delay.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Maybe the Level-2 agents are backlogged or there's a lack of resources when tickets are escalated. Or maybe the process for handling escalated tickets isn't efficient, causing delays.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Also, considering the total time, some cases took multiple days. For example, 102 and 104 took over a day, and 105 took almost two days. This could be due to the agents not being available during certain times, or perhaps the investigation steps themselves took longer because the issues were more complex.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: To fix this, resource allocation and process efficiency in the escalation and investigation phases need improvement.
